s.text: Such a limpid production provides a window into the merits and flaws of the play itself.

In all his plays, Miller remains fixed to the same set of concerns: corruption and the worship of material success; loyalty and betrayal; fathers and sons; public responsibility and personal conscience.
But Miller's career is a testament to the opposite problem: creative paralysis brought on by early success.

In all his plays, Miller remains fixed to the same set of concerns: corruption and the worship of material success; loyalty and betrayal; fathers and sons; public responsibility and personal conscience.

In all his plays, Miller remains fixed to the same set of concerns: corruption and the worship of material success; loyalty and betrayal; fathers and sons; public responsibility and personal conscience.
But Miller's career is a testament to the opposite problem: creative paralysis brought on by early success.

In all his plays, Miller remains fixed to the same set of concerns: corruption and the worship of material success; loyalty and betrayal; fathers and sons; public responsibility and personal conscience.
Willy's pushing his sons to succeed and his unwillingness to accept their failures develop into delusion and insanity.
Willy's pushing his sons to succeed and his unwillingness to accept their failures develop into delusion and insanity.
Willy's pushing his sons to succeed and his unwillingness to accept their failures develop into delusion and insanity.
Almost everything else about the production is equally strong.
As a dramatist, Miller not only has no sense of humor, he also fails to grasp how changes in tone and texture can be used to make tragedy tolerable.
On the basis of these four works, written over a period of only eight years, Miller is frequently referred to as America's greatest living playwright.
Phillip Gellburg is an upscale Willy Loman who has devoted his life to a company that throws him onto the slag heap as soon as he begins to falter.
As his ideas grew familiar and then stale, he found no way to complicate them, develop them, or move on to something else.
As his ideas grew familiar and then stale, he found no way to complicate them, develop them, or move on to something else.

They're either saintly, maternal figures (Kate Keller in All My Sons , Linda Loman in Death of a Salesman , Elizabeth Proctor in The Crucible ) or destructive temptresses (Abigail Williams in The Crucible , Catherine in A View From the Bridge , Maggie in After the Fall ). The lack of interest in women's minds is another thing that dates Miller and makes even his more recent plays seem like period pieces.
